s.text: In armored scales, the bacteriome has exactly the same genome (two complete copies of the mother's diploid genome and one complete copy of the father's genome) in all full siblings, whether they are male or female, and the same is usually true in mealybugs.
This temptation increases when we consider another case from the old cytogenetics literature of apparent histological eusociality, though not of true permanent chimerism.
The study of truly strange creatures can tell us what kinds of things are possible.

In the case of armored scale insect chimerism, the bacteriome does have a copy of the paternal genome, and that copy is identical to the paternal genome in the rest of the embryo, so in that sense the two tissues do have a high relatedness similar to the high relatedness of full siblings under haplodiploidy.
But a typical animal is a clone in the sense that all its cells arise from that single fertilized egg cell.
When the phenomena were discovered, early in the 20th century, the theoretical tools for making sense of them were unavailable.
That's why we will be so interested in any life found on another planet and why, in the meantime, we should take a close look at scale insects.
For instance, although humans are not usually chimeras, we do have a quasi-chimeric phase in our life cycle: pregnancy.
